sections.heading: Introduction to Machine Learning and Supervised Learning

bullets.text: Machine learning teaches computers to learn from data instead of explicit rules.
Supervised learning trains systems on labeled data to predict unseen cases.
Example: An email marked as spam or not spam.
Common algorithms include decision trees, support vector machines, and neural networks.
Unsupervised learning finds patterns in data without labels.
Example: K-means for clustering customers based on purchasing behavior.
Reinforcement learning involves an agent learning from feedback or rewards in an environment.
Example: Training AI to play video games or control a robot.
Overfitting occurs when a model memorizes training data but performs poorly on new data.
Bias arises when the training data itself is not balanced.
Applications include disease prediction in healthcare.
Used in finance for fraud detection.
Essential for object recognition in self-driving cars.
